Award.AwardTitle: Partnership for Research and Education in Materials: Partnership for Advanced Functional Metamaterials (Meta-PREM)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Partnership for Advanced Functional Metamaterials (Meta-PREM)

Throughout human history, new materials have played a pivotal role in the development of technologies and the progress of whole civilizations. Terms such as Stone Age, Bronze Age, or Silicon Valley underscore the defining societal impact that the discovery or harnessing of a new material can foment. The beginning of the 21st century has coincided with the invention of an entirely new materials platform - metamaterials - engineered multi-phase composite materials containing inclusions that often have tailored shapes, sizes, mutual arrangements and orientations. Such materials exhibit unparalleled responses to many types of wave excitations, including electromagnetic, acoustic and thermal.

Many applications of metamaterials systems and devices, e.g. next-generation electronics operating at optical frequencies, require both passive and active (amplifying or nonlinear) components. The development of metamaterials over the past decade has focused primarily on passive metamaterials. One of the two research foci of the Partnership is aimed at the development of active metamaterials: tunable, nonlinear, and amplifying. The other intriguing class of metamaterials, whose development has been pioneered by the team members, is metamaterials with hyperbolic dispersion. In one direction, the response of these unique materials to electromagnetic waves is similar to that of metals. However, in an orthogonal direction, it is similar to that of dielectrics. The studies of unparalleled classical and quantum properties of such materials (including spontaneous emission, energy transfer, and many others) comprise the second research focus of Meta-PREM. The research will be performed in a highly collaborative manner by the partners with complementary expertise and capabilities.

Meta-PREM integrates the research and education efforts of a historically black university, Norfolk State University, and three research-intensive institutions, Michigan State University, Purdue University and Cornell University. The project's education and outreach activities flow from identified complementary strengths of the partners. This synergy allows for a range of relevant programs that will benefit a diverse body of students in the full spectrum of the education continuum, especially at the graduate level. Norfolk State University's Ph.D. program in materials science and engineering is only five years old, being the only STEM doctoral program on campus. By integrating NSU's students and faculty with those at well-established graduate programs, Meta-PREM will accelerate the young doctoral program towards maturation, effectively increasing the capacity to produce a more diverse group of highly trained materials science professionals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Optical metamaterials are nanostructured composite materials, which allow one to manipulate light in unprecedented way and lead to nearly fantastic applications and functionalities, ranging from invisibility cloaking to ultra-high resolution imaging. Many applications require metamaterials, which can be tunable in real time and which can control physical phenomena beyond bending, reflecting and transmitting visible light. The study of the latter two classes of metamaterials was the major focus of the PREM research. Among multiple Intellectual Merit accomplishments of the PREM project , three are particularly noteworthy. (i) We have fabricated and characterized the VO2/Au multilayered metamaterial, which undergoes a phase transition and whose transmission, reflection and dispersion can be controlled with temperature. (ii) We have demonstrated that lamellar metal/dielectric metamaterials can control (inhibit) energy transfer between donor and acceptor molecules. (iii) We have also demonstrated that the latter lamellar metamaterials can control the rates of chemical reactions, in particular, photodegradation and chemiluminescence. These findings advance the research field of metamaterials and lead to new potential applications.

The Broader Impacts of PREM were two-fold: (i) student development and (ii) dissemination of the research findings.

Nearly 200 graduate, undergraduate, and high school students (many of them from underrepresented minority groups) participated in research and professional development activities of PREM. More specific, PREM served 54 graduate students (from Norfolk State University and partner Institutions),  45 Academic Year undergraduate students, 39 Summer undergraduate students, 13 Academic Year high school students and 30 Summer high school students. Multiple students participated in PREM over several years in different capacities, e.g. first as an undergraduate student and then as a graduate student, exemplifying the academic  pipeline established by the PREM program. The efficiency of this pipeline can be highlighted by multiple success stories, including PREM high school students going to Cornell and Caltech, PREM undergraduate student going to the graduate program in Georgia Tech, and PREM graduate students getting postdoctoral positions with Lawrence Livermore National lab and RICE university as well as getting tenure-track positions in teaching universities.

The results of the PREM program were presented at 165 national and international conferences (116 presentations co-authored by students) and published in 67 reviewed research papers (51 papers co-authored by students).
